turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That was Billy Ansel on the phone. He wants to come over to talk to us.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Did he say what about?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Was he drinking?  Could you tell?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jenny, it's time for you to go to bed.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Is he coming over now?  Right away?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's what he said.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hey, Billy!  What brings you out on a night like this?  C'mon in.  Take a load off.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Would you like a cup of tea, Billy? There's a piece of cake left.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: The Pied Piper of Hamelin. By famous Hanover city; The river Weser, deep and wide, Washes its wall on the southern side; A pleasanter spot you never spied; But, when begins my ditty...

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: What's a ditty again?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: It's like a song.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: What's vermin again?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Rats! They fought the dogs and killed the cats, And bit the babies in the cradles, And ate the cheeses out of vats. And licked the soup from the cook's own ladles, Split open the kegs of salted sprats, Made nests inside men's Sunday hats, And even spoiled the women's chats, By drowning their speaking With shrieking and squeaking In fifty different sharps and flats...

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Nicole?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Can I sit beside you on the bus tomorrow?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Don't you usually like to sit at the back?  To wave at your Dad?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: I want to sit beside you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Nicole?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: What, Mason?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Well, if he knew magic - if he could get the kids into the mountain - why couldn't he use his pipe to make the people pay him for getting rid of the rats?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Because...he wanted to them to be punished.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: The people in the town?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: So he was mean?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.  Not mean.  Just...very angry.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Should I keep reading?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I don't like thinking about the accident.  I don't even remember it happening.  Besides, it just makes people feel sorry for me, and...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You hate that.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: You can only feel lucky that you didn't die for so long.  Then you start to feel...unlucky.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That you didn't die?  Like the other children?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.  Like Bear and the Ansel twins and Sean and...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It would be strange if you didn't feel that way.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: What do you want me to do for you, Mr. Stephens?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: They work for the people we're trying to sue.  Their job is to try to minimize damages.  Our job, Nicole, is to try to maximize them. You have to think of it that way. As people doing their jobs.  No good guys or bad guys.  Just our side and their side.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I won't lie.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I don't want you to lie.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: The truth is that it was an accident, and no one's to blame.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: There's no such thing as an accident, Nicole.  Not in a situation like this.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: You seem very sure about that.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm absolutely positive.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Dolores.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.  Dolores...and even your mom and dad.  But I'll make sure you go last.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: So you can keep on getting well before you have to go and do this. It's not going to be easy, Nicole. Do you understand that?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: It was snowing.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Unless the report from the National Weather Bureau for the district on January 23 goes into the record, I will object to that question.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I object to the form of that question.  Note that.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Was the bus on time?

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: There was nothing reckless in Mrs. Driscoll's behavior?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I object to that form of question. Note that.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Note my objection.  She said, 'As I'm talking.'

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Did there come a time when the bus turned off Staples Mill Road onto

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Note that she said 'pretty clearly'. Not 'clearly'.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: And what was the weather like at this time?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I have no questions.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Thank you, Nicole.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Do you have a room?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Will you be spending more than a night?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Hard to say.  I might have...some business here.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What about Doreen?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: She...she was a friend of mine.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: At school.  She fell for Kyle just before we graduated.  Got pregnant, and...went to live in a trailer up on a woodlot Kyle's dad used to own. Kyle started spending more and more time at the Spread Eagle...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's the local bar?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: ...coming home drunk and I guess feeling trapped by his life and blaming her for that...and...

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: People who will help our cause.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's great, Wendell.  That's the sort of thing I need to know.  So it doesn't come back to haunt our case later on.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: There's the Prescots...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Tell me about the Ottos.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Wanda and Hartley.  They lost Bear. He was their adopted son.  A beautiful boy.  Indian.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Indian?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's good.  Judges like adopted Indian boys.  Tell me more about the Ottos.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: They're smart.  Been to college. They moved here from the city about a dozen years ago.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What do they do?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Crafts.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Crafts?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Wanda does these photographic things.  That's one of her pictures on the wall.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Have they ever been busted?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Need a hand?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sure, it you could find a towel in this bag.  I know my wife packed one in there...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You always think you're prepared for these things.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: How old is she?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Almost three.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Is this it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Perfect.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Here we go.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm in a car wash.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: A car wash!  Wow, I've never talked to you when you've been in a car wash.  Make sure you've got the windows closed.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Remember that time we were having the car washed and I started playing with the automatic window?  How old was I, Daddy?  Five or six?  I got absolutely soaked, remember?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Why are you calling me, Zoe?

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Why am I calling you?  You're my father.  I'm not supposed to call you?  What's the matter with wanting to talk to you, Daddy?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Nothing's wrong with trying to talk to me, Zoe.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: So what's the problem?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: The problem is I have no idea who I'm talking to right now.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: 'Cause you think I'm stoned, Daddy? 'Cause you think I've got a needle stuck in my arm?  Is that what you're thinking, Daddy?

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: DADDY!!!

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Why can't you talk to me?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I...I just need to know what state you're in so I know...how to talk to you...how to act...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes, I'll accept the charges.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Daddy?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: I'm calling because I've got some news for you, Daddy.  Some big news.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: News?

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Don't you want to hear?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.  Give me your news, Zoe.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: You always think you know what I'm going to say, don't you?  You always think you're two steps ahead of me. The lawyer.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Tell me your news, Zoe.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Okay.  I went to sell blood yesterday.  That's how it is.  I'm in this fucking city where my father is a hot shit lawyer, and I'm selling my blood.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's not news, Zoe.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: No.  But this is.  They wouldn't take my blood.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Do you know what that means, Daddy? Does it register?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: I tested positive.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Welcome to hard times, Daddy.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What do you want me to do, Zoe? I'll do whatever you want.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: I need money.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: You can't ask me that!  Not anymore! You asked me what I wanted.  Not what I wanted it for.  I want money.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Do you have the blood test?

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: You don't believe me?  You don't fucking believe me?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Of...course I do.  I just thought...I could get you another

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: I can hear you breathing, Daddy.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.  I can hear you breathing too.

turns.speaker: ZOE
turns.text: Oh God, I'm scared.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I love you, Zoe.  I'll be there soon, and I'll take care of you.  No matter what happens.  I'll take care of you.

turns.speaker: STEWARDESS
turns.text: Some more wine?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm afraid this meat is overdone.

turns.speaker: STEWARDESS
turns.text: I'm sorry about that, Mr. Stephens. Would you like to try the fish?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: STEWARDESS
turns.text: Poached salmon.

turns.speaker: STEWARDESS
turns.text: We do.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Is there shrimp on it?

turns.speaker: STEWARDESS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: If you could pick the shrimp off, as well as anything that touches the shrimp...

turns.speaker: STEWARDESS
turns.text: I'm not sure if that will leave much on the plate.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Well, let's see what we get.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm sorry for coming over unannounced like this, Mrs. Otto, but the Walkers said you would understand.  I know it's an awful time, but it's important that we talk.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm a lawyer.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: You can't come here.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Please, let me explain.  I'll only take a moment of your time.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: The Walkers spoke very highly of you.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: You've been retained?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Their child died, and they got a lawyer.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It should be said that my task is to represent the Walkers only in their anger.  Not their grief.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Who did they get for that?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You are angry, aren't you, Mrs. Otto?  That's why I'm here.  To give your anger a voice.  To be your

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Dolores?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It's my belief that Dolores was doing exactly what she'd been doing for years.  Besides, the school board's insurance on Dolores is minimal.  A few million at the very most.  The really deep pockets are to be found in the town, or in the company that made the bus.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: You think someone else caused the accident?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Mrs.  Otto,  there is no such thing as an accident.  The word doesn't mean anything to me.  As far as I'm concerned, somebody somewhere made a decision to cut a corner.  Some corrupt agency or corporation accounted the cost variance between a ten-cent bolt and a million dollar out-of-court settlement.  They decided to sacrifice a few lives for the difference.  That's what's done, Mrs. Otto.  I've seen it happen so many times before.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: So you're just the thing we need.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Isn't that what you want us to believe?  That we're completely defenseless?  That you know what's best?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Listen to me, Mrs Otto.  Listen very carefully.  I do know what's best.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Are you expensive?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: If you agree to have me represent you in this suit, I will require no payment until after the case is won, when I will require one third of the awarded amount.  If there is no award made, then my services will cost you nothing.  It's a standard agreement.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Do you have this agreement with you?

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Are you a reporter?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Kyle Lambston's a drunk.  Nobody likes him.  He's a nasty piece of work.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: In what way?

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Been drinking since high school. Fucked himself up.  Used to be smart enough.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Any criminal record?

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Probably half a dozen traffic convictions.  Drunk driving.  Lost his licence.  That's why he don't work no more.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Can't get off that shitty dump they live on.  What little money comes in goes to booze.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: How does the family survive?

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Don't know.  Food banks, welfare, church charity.  They scrape by.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Now on that morning, did there come a time, Nicole, when you left your parents' house?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: What time in the morning was this?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: About eight-thirty in the morning.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Was anyone waiting for the bus with you?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.  I was alone.  My sister Jenny was sick and stayed home that day.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Was there anything unusual about the driver, Dolores Driscoll, or the bus that particular morning?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Like what?  I mean, I don't remember a lot.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: And where did you sit that morning?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: My usual place.  On the right side. The first seat.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: And according to your recollection, there was nothing unusual about the drive that morning?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Until the accident?  No.  Yes, there was.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Did there come a time when all the children had been picked up?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: You remember that much?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: As I'm talking, I'm remembering more about it.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: There was a brown dog that ran across the road up there, right by the dump, and Dolores slowed down not to hit him, and he ran into the woods.  And then Dolores drove on and turned onto the Marlowe road, as usual.  I remember that.  I'm remembering it pretty clearly.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: You are?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: I will offer that report.  Well, then, now that your memory seems to be clearing, can you tell us what else  you observed at that time?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Before the actual accident?

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I was scared.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Why were you scared?

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: This is before the accident, Nicole. Do you understand what I'm asking?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes, I understand.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Why were you scared?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Dolores was driving too fast.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Mrs.  Driscoll was driving too fast? What made you think that, Nicole?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: The speedometer.  And it was downhill there.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: You could see the speedometer?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.  I looked.  I remember clearly now.  It seemed we were going too fast down the hill.  I was scared.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: How fast would you say Mrs. Driscoll was going?  To the best of your recollection?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Seventy-two miles an hour.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Seventy-two miles an hour?  You're sure of this?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Positive.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: You believe that the bus driven by Mrs. Driscoll was going at seventy- two miles an hour at this time?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I told you I was positive.  The speedometer was large and easy to see from where I was.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: You saw the speedometer?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Did you say anything to Mrs. Driscoll?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I was scared.  And there wasn't time.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: There wasn't time?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.  Because the bus went off the road.  And crashed.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: You remember this?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Yes.  I do now.  Now that I'm telling it.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: What do you remember about the accident?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I remember the bus swerved, it just suddenly swerved to the right, and it hit the guardrail and the snowbank on the side of the road, and then it went over the embankment there, and everyone was screaming and everything.  And that's all.  I guess I was unconscious after that. That's all.  Then I was in the hospital.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That was great.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You're going to blow everyone away.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: You mean it?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: You don't sound like one hundred percent absolutely sure.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I am.  Really.  It was awesome.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What's so funny?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Just the way Dolores gets so excited about bringing the kids to check out the animals.  It's like the biggest thing in her life.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What took so long?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Mrs.  Ansel's clothing.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Does it fit?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: They say I'm lucky because I can't remember the accident.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Don't even try to remember.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: How do you like it, Nicole?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: The ramp?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Pretty slick, eh?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Very slick.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Do you like the colour?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: It's okay.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And I had to widen a few doors. You'll see.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: The door needs a lock.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sure.  I'll fix it right away.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: That's too high.  I'll never reach it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Oh.  I better get some spackle.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He's a lawyer.  He's our lawyer.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: You and Mom have a lawyer?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, yes.  He's your lawyer too.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: My lawyer?  Why do I need a lawyer?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It's because of the accident, Nicole.  Most people in this town whose kids were on the bus have got lawyers.  A lot of people...well, people in this town are very angry. Us included.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: But you didn't lose me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You're going to need special care for a long time to come.  It's not going to be easy.  Not for you, not for any of us.  Because we love you so much.  And it's going to cost money.  More than we can imagine.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: What about insurance?  Doesn't insurance pay for these things?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Partly.  But there's a lot the insurance doesn't cover.  That's one of the reasons we have a lawyer.  To make sure the insurance gets paid and to help us look after the rest.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: How will he do that?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, Mr. Stephens is representing several families.  The Ottos, the Walkers, us, and I think a couple more.  Mr. Stephens is suing the town for negligence.  He's sure that the accident could have been avoided if they had done their jobs right. He's a very smart man.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What are you up to, Nicole?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nothing good on your T.V.?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: As opposed to this T.V.?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Are you sleeping?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nicole, tomorrow Mr. Stephens wants you to make your deposition at the courthouse.  I thought I'd take you over.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You seem...I don't know...well, distant, I guess.  Hard to talk to.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I mean I'm a wheelchair girl now. It's hard to pretend I'm a beautiful rock star.  Not like you used to tell me.  Remember, Daddy?  All the people that were going to discover me?  Where are they now?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: He couldn't look at me.  But I looked at him.  Right at him.  His secret was mine now.  We used to share it.  But not anymore.  Now, I owned it completely.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, okay.  I'll take you about nine-thirty in the morning.  That's okay with you?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: How about Sunday night?  That's always the best time.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: What's going to happen to Dolores?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Will the police do anything to her?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It's too late for that.  She can't drive the bus anymore.  The school board saw to that right off.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: She'll move away.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: There's talk of that.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Someplace where no one knows her.  Someplace strange and new.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Well, there's the Hamiltons.  Joe and Shelly Hamilton.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Yeah, right.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: That sonofabitch owes thousands to the bank and half the businesses in town.  He's about to lose his house and car.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: But Charlene...

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Charlene's over at the Spread Eagle every other night.  Sleeps with whatever she can get her hands on. She'll go down for a pat on the head and a fistful of peanuts.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Don't even think of the Bilodeaus or the Atwaters.  They're all inbred.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: The Ottos.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Yeah, well, they probably smoke weed.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: You don't know that.

turns.speaker: BARTHA
turns.text: Loretta...Sidney Falco...

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: How do you do, Mr. Falco.  If you know anything about horses, sit a minute.  Help yourself to a glass of this N.Y. State champagne - that's what my husband buys me.

turns.speaker: BARTHA
turns.text: You ought to stop this nonsense, Loretta, these two dollar bets.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: It's compensation, Leo, for the marginal life we lead.  Sidney, did you hear the story about the cloak-and-suitor who -- ?

turns.speaker: BARTHA
turns.text: That's right!  Tell him, so I can read it in Hunsecker's column first!

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Oh, are you a spy for the other side?

turns.speaker: BARTHA
turns.text: Will you mind your own business!

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Hitler!

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Where are we running?  What am I missing here?

turns.speaker: BARTHA
turns.text: Waiter, the check.  This man is trying to hold a gun to my head!

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: That's the horse!  Shotgun - Shotgun in the fifth!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: How are you tonight, Mr. Falco?

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Is "he" inside?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: But of course...

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Alone or surrounded?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: A Senator, an Agent and Something - With - Long - Red - Hair.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Hello, Sidney.  Wanna table?

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Just hopping tonight.  Leo Bartha been in?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Yeah, having supper with the Mrs. She's over there.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: He's somewhere...

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Thanks, I see him...

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Come on boys, break it up...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: The next time you want information, Falco, don't scratch for it like a dog - ask for it like a man!

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Did she accept?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You don't like it, do you.  I think she will accept, but I'm not sure. She may be too dependent on her brother.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Excuse me, Steve.  I said namely you shouldn't go around wild, blaming people without justification.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I thought you might have a faint idea of how this item originated.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Boys, this gets nobody nowhere - you're over excited, Steve and -

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Don't apologize for me, Frank!

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: ...excited with good reason, I wanted to say.  Because this endangers the future of the whole quintet...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I want to speak to Miss Hunsecker, please.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: We're on our way there now...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I still think he's responsible for the smear.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Not that I'm convinced, but you'll never prove it in a million years.  Steve, you'll do what you want, but it can't hurt; he offers you an olive branch - so today like olives!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I guess you're right, but -

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: I could think of better places to meet her, instead of here.  He lives on the whole top floor.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I doubt that it matters any more.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Joe, give my nephew a drink.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Your nephew doesn't want a drink.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: That's a lollipop that, boy.  The kid is only great.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: And with ten percent of his future, you're great, too, Frank.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Went over to Philly yesterday an' seen the folks...it's nice you send them the fifty a month...

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: See my mother?

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: I only had a few hours.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Thanks for the publicity spread you got the boys for the benefit tomorrow.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Robard's my client.  I did it for him and his club, not your boys.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Frank, I think maybe you lied to me.

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Looka, Sidney, you're my own sister's son, but where does that give you the right to call me a liar?

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: You told me that your boy was washed up with Susie Hunsecker, didn't you?

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Yeah, and it's the truth, to the best of my knowledge.  And, frankly, I'm glad.  For Steve's sake, I'm glad, not yours.  I manage these boys and I got their best interests at heart.  Steve shouldn't get mixed up with no bimbo at his age.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: You told him that?

turns.speaker: D'ANGELO
turns.text: Not in those exact words - you know what a temper he's got.
